meditation_prompts.instruction: Find a comfortable posture. Close your eyes and bring your attention to the natural rhythm of your breath. Notice the sensation of the air entering and leaving your body without trying to change it.
Bring your awareness to the soles of your feet. Notice any sensations—warmth, tingling, pressure—without judgment. Slowly move your attention up through your body, one section at a time.
Sit quietly and open your awareness to the sounds around you. Notice sounds near and far, loud and soft. Simply listen, without labeling the sounds as 'good' or 'bad'.
Bring to mind someone you care about deeply. Silently repeat the phrases: 'May you be happy. May you be healthy. May you be safe. May you live with ease.'
Choose a simple object in your environment. Gaze at it for a few minutes, noticing its colors, textures, and shape as if you are seeing it for the very first time.
As thoughts arise, label them gently as 'thinking'. Imagine them as clouds passing in the sky, allowing them to come and go without getting caught up in their stories.
Bring to mind three things you are genuinely grateful for, no matter how small. For each one, hold it in your mind and feel the sensation of gratitude in your body.
Focus on the sensation of your breath at the tip of your nose. Feel the coolness of the in-breath and the warmth of the out-breath. Use this as an anchor for your attention.
Focus on the sensations in your hands. Notice the temperature, the feeling of the air on your skin, the contact with any surface. Explore this small area with your full attention.
Listen for the most distant sound you can perceive. Then, listen for the closest sound. Alternate between these two points of focus, expanding and contracting your awareness.
Direct feelings of kindness toward yourself. Place a hand on your heart and silently repeat: 'May I be happy. May I be healthy. May I be safe. May I live with ease.'
Look at your own hands. Observe the lines, creases, colors, and shapes with a curious and non-judgmental attention.
Notice any emotion present right now. Where do you feel it in your body? Breathe into that area, creating space around the sensation without trying to change it.
Bring to mind someone who is struggling. Acknowledge their pain and extend a sense of compassion, silently wishing them peace and freedom from suffering.
Count your breaths. Inhale one, exhale one. Inhale two, exhale two. Count up to ten, and then begin again. If you lose track, gently return to one.
Bring your awareness to your face. Notice the small muscles around your eyes, jaw, and forehead. Consciously release any tension you find there.
Focus on the sensation of your clothes against your skin or your body making contact with the chair. Explore the feeling of pressure, texture, and temperature.
Think of someone you see regularly but don't have strong feelings about (e.g., a cashier, a bus driver). Extend wishes of well-being to them, recognizing your shared humanity.
Observe the play of light and shadow in the room around you. Notice how light falls on different surfaces and creates different shapes.
Notice the space between your thoughts. In the brief gap after one thought ends and before another begins, rest your awareness in that stillness.
Contemplate the changing nature of your breath. Each breath is unique—it has a beginning, a middle, and an end. It arises and passes away, just like all phenomena.
Focus on the gentle rising and falling of your abdomen as you breathe. Let this be a calming anchor for your mind.
Scan your body for any areas that feel relaxed and at ease. Rest your attention there, savoring the feeling of comfort.
Sit with a wide-open awareness, allowing thoughts, sounds, and physical sensations to come and go without focusing on any single thing. Simply be the space in which everything happens.
Bring to mind someone with whom you have a difficult relationship. If you can, extend a simple wish for their well-being, such as 'May you be free from suffering.'
Walk slowly, paying full attention to the sensation of your feet making contact with the ground. Notice the lifting, moving, and placing of each foot.
Acknowledge any feeling present by naming it softly in your mind, such as 'This is sadness' or 'This is joy.' Naming the emotion can help create distance from it.
Reflect on a simple modern convenience you enjoy (like running water or electricity). Consider what life would be like without it and cultivate a sense of gratitude.
Imagine your breath as a wave, flowing in and flowing out. Ride the rhythm of this wave with your attention.
Scan your body, noticing where you feel energetic and where you feel tired. Don't try to change anything, just observe the landscape of your physical energy.
Pay attention to the silence between sounds. Notice the brief pauses and gaps in the soundscape around you.
Expand your circle of kindness to include all living beings everywhere. Silently repeat: 'May all beings be happy. May all beings be safe. May all beings be free.'
If you are near a window, watch the movement of clouds or leaves in the wind. Observe the constant, gentle change.
When a strong thought or worry appears, ask yourself: 'Is this thought helpful right now?' Gently guide your attention back to your breath.
Think of a recent mistake or failing. Offer yourself the same compassion you would offer a dear friend in the same situation. Acknowledge that to be human is to be imperfect.
Notice the four parts of your breath: the inhalation, the pause at the top, the exhalation, and the pause at the bottom. Rest your attention on this full cycle.
Bring your awareness to the entire container of your body. Feel the outline of your physical form and the sense of it being a whole, interconnected system.
Without moving your eyes, notice the colors in your peripheral vision. Gently expand your awareness to take in the full spectrum of color around you.
Bring to mind a group of people (your family, your coworkers, your community). Hold them all in your awareness and extend wishes of well-being to the entire group.
If you are in a conversation today, practice listening to understand, rather than listening to reply. Give the other person your full, present attention.
Notice the 'flavor' of your current emotional state. Is it calm, agitated, joyful, heavy? Acknowledge it without judgment.
Reflect on the fact that this current moment, exactly as it is, will never happen again. This can bring a sense of preciousness to the present.
As you inhale, silently say 'In'. As you exhale, silently say 'Out'. Use these simple labels to keep your mind anchored.
Scan your body for any sensations of tightness or contraction. As you breathe out, imagine those areas softening and releasing, even just a little.
Rest in a state of choiceless awareness. Whatever comes into your attention—a thought, a feeling, a sound—is welcome. Simply notice it and let it be.
Bring to mind a person who has helped you or shown you kindness. Silently thank them in your heart.
When you have your next meal or snack, take the first bite with your full attention. Notice the flavors, textures, and smells as if for the first time.
Recognize that your thoughts are not facts. They are mental events that arise and pass away. You don't have to believe them or act on them.
Think about the shared human desire to be happy and to avoid suffering. Reflect on how this connects you to every other person on the planet.
Follow one single breath from the very beginning of the inhalation all the way to the very end of the exhalation. Give it your complete attention.
Notice the subtle sensation of your heartbeat. Feel this gentle rhythm, a constant sign of life within you.
Listen to the sounds within your own body—your breath, your heartbeat, the rumbling of digestion. Explore your internal soundscape.
Bring yourself to mind and wish yourself peace. Then, bring a loved one to mind and wish them peace. See if you can extend this feeling of peace outward.
Find a plant or flower and observe it closely. Notice the details of its structure, its colors, and any signs of life and growth.
When a difficult emotion arises, ask 'What does this feeling need?' Does it need acceptance? Kindness? Space? Listen for the answer.
Consider the clothes you are wearing. Reflect on the many people and processes involved in creating them and bringing them to you (farmers, factory workers, drivers, etc.).
Notice how your body breathes itself. You don't have to do anything; the process happens on its own. Rest in this natural, effortless rhythm.
Bring a gentle, kind awareness to an area of your body where you experience chronic pain or discomfort. Breathe into it with a sense of softness and care, not resistance.
Take a moment to notice the scents in the air around you. Are they faint or strong? Pleasant or neutral? Just observe.
Imagine someone you love smiling. Hold that image in your mind and allow it to bring a sense of warmth and joy.
The next time you are waiting in line or for something to load, use it as an opportunity to practice. Notice your breath and the sensations in your body instead of reaching for your phone.
Notice the tone of your thoughts. Are they critical, worried, neutral, kind? Simply observe the quality of your inner monologue.
Reflect on one part of your body that works well and that you are grateful for. It could be your eyes that see, your legs that walk, or your lungs that breathe.
Feel the sensation of your whole body breathing. With each in-breath, feel your body subtly expand; with each out-breath, feel it soften.
Notice the points of contact your body is making with the floor or furniture. Feel the solidness and support of the surface beneath you.
Let your awareness be like the sky—vast, open, and allowing all 'weather' (thoughts, feelings, sensations) to pass through without resistance.
Recall a time someone was compassionate toward you. Reconnect with how that felt, and consider how you might offer that feeling to someone else today.
Pick one routine chore today (like brushing your teeth) and do it with your full attention. Notice all the physical sensations involved.
Investigate a pleasant emotion. Where do you feel joy, contentment, or peace in your body? Savor the physical sensation of it.
Notice a sound from its beginning to its end. Observe how it arises, lingers for a moment, and then fades away into silence.
Imagine your in-breath gathering calm and your out-breath releasing tension. Breathe in calm, breathe out tension.
Feel the space inside your body. Notice the sense of volume and openness within your torso, arms, and legs.
Categorize the sounds you hear as 'pleasant', 'unpleasant', or 'neutral'. Notice if you have a tendency to resist the unpleasant sounds or cling to the pleasant ones.
Offer well-wishes to someone you saw today but do not know. Acknowledge their humanity and wish them well on their journey.
Notice the way your own facial expression feels from the inside. Are your muscles tense or relaxed?
Instead of saying 'I am angry,' try reframing it as 'There is a feeling of anger present.' This creates a little space between you and the emotion.
Be grateful for your challenges. Reflect on how a past difficulty has helped you grow stronger or wiser.
Match the length of your inhalation to the length of your exhalation for a few cycles, creating a sense of balance.
Bring your awareness to your shoulders and neck, a common area for holding stress. Gently invite any tension there to soften and release.
When you drink a glass of water, notice the sensation of the coolness and the feeling of it quenching your thirst. Savor this simple act.
Acknowledge that you are doing the best you can with the resources you have in this moment. Offer yourself a moment of grace.
Before you pick up your phone, pause. Ask yourself: 'What is my intention?' Notice if you are acting out of habit or conscious choice.
When an urge arises (e.g., to check email, eat a snack), just notice it as a physical sensation. Observe how it grows, peaks, and eventually subsides on its own if you don't act on it.
Consider the air you are breathing. It has been shared by countless other beings and plants. Feel this connection to the web of life.
Focus on your exhalation. With each out-breath, feel a sense of letting go, releasing, and settling.
Notice the subtle movements in your body, even when sitting still—your chest moving with your breath, your pulse, small shifts in posture.
Sit and simply be aware of 'what is here now?' Welcome whatever arises into your field of awareness without needing to do anything about it.
Think of someone who has inspired you. Send them feelings of gratitude and well-wishes.
Notice patterns in your environment—the grain of wood, the weave of fabric, the arrangement of tiles on the floor.
When a worrying thought arises, label it 'worrying'. This simple act can reduce its power and remind you that it is just a thought.
Be grateful for the gift of this day. Acknowledge that having this time is a precious opportunity.
Let your breath be your anchor in the present moment. Whenever your mind wanders, gently guide it back to the physical sensation of breathing.
Feel the weight and solidity of your body. Sense its presence and groundedness on the earth.
Notice the beginning, middle, and end of a single sound. Pay attention to its entire lifecycle.
Bring to mind all the people who are working right now to make your life possible (e.g., farmers, utility workers, healthcare professionals). Send them a feeling of gratitude and support.
When you move from one task to another today, take one conscious breath as a moment of pause to reset your attention.
Recognize that emotions are like weather—they are not permanent and will eventually pass. Observe your inner weather without getting swept away.
Reflect on a past version of yourself. Acknowledge how much you have changed, demonstrating the fluid, unfixed nature of identity.
Let your awareness rest in the pause after the exhale. Notice the stillness and quiet in that moment before the next breath begins.
For a few minutes, sit quietly and simply rest. After months of focused practice, allow yourself a moment of pure, objectless being. Notice what that feels like.
Place a hand on your belly and feel it rise and fall with each breath. This can enhance the sensation and help keep you grounded.
Notice the overall temperature of your body. Are there areas that feel warmer or cooler than others? Just observe without judgment.
Imagine your ears are microphones, passively receiving all sounds without discrimination. Let the entire symphony of sounds wash over you.
Bring a good friend to mind. Hold their image and silently wish them everything you would wish for yourself: happiness, health, and peace.
Let your eyes rest softly on a point in front of you. Without straining, simply take in the visual information in your field of vision.
As thoughts arise, categorize them: 'planning,' 'remembering,' 'judging,' 'fantasizing.' This shows you the patterns of your mind.
Thank your body for all the work it does without your conscious effort—digesting food, fighting illness, healing wounds. Appreciate its innate intelligence.
Notice how the breath feels in your throat and chest. Follow the sensation as the air travels down and then back up.
Focus on your jaw. Consciously unclench it, letting your teeth part slightly and your tongue rest comfortably in your mouth. Notice the release of tension.
Listen for the rhythm or pattern in the sounds around you, whether it's traffic, birdsong, or the hum of an appliance.
Direct kind wishes to your own body. 'May this body be strong. May this body be healthy. May this body be free from pain.'
If possible, look at a tree. Observe its stillness and strength, its roots grounded in the earth and its branches reaching for the sky.
Gently ask yourself, 'What am I feeling right now?' Allow the answer to arise without needing to fix or analyze it. Just acknowledge its presence.
Remind yourself that everyone you meet is fighting a battle you know nothing about. Let this thought cultivate a sense of gentleness and patience toward others.
Try counting your breaths backward from ten. Exhale ten, inhale ten. Exhale nine, inhale nine. If your mind wanders, gently start again from ten.
Bring awareness to the posture of your spine. Gently lengthen it, creating a sense of dignity and alertness in your posture.
Notice the moments of stillness in your body between movements. Feel the pause before you shift or adjust your position.
Bring your neighborhood or local community to mind. Extend wishes of safety, peace, and well-being to all who live there.
Choose a color and notice all the places it appears in your immediate environment. Let your eyes gently scan for just that one color.
Notice if a thought is about the past or the future. Gently acknowledge its time-frame ('past' or 'future') and return your attention to the present moment.
Focus on a physical sensation. Notice how it is not static; it may change in intensity, location, or quality from moment to moment.
Imagine breathing in energy and vitality, and breathing out any sluggishness or fatigue.
Feel the sensation of your feet on the floor. Imagine roots growing down from your feet, grounding you to the earth.
Allow your awareness to be boundless, with no center and no edge. Rest in this open, spacious quality of mind.
Bring to mind a small hurt you have caused someone else. Acknowledge it without judgment and silently ask for forgiveness, letting go of self-blame.
Slowly stretch your arms overhead. Pay full attention to the sensations in your muscles, joints, and skin as you move.
When a challenging emotion is present, place a hand over your heart as a gesture of self-soothing and compassion. Breathe with the feeling.
Be grateful for the chair that is supporting you, the roof over your head, and the air you are breathing. Acknowledge these simple supports.
Focus on the physical sensation of air filling your lungs. Feel the expansion in your chest and rib cage.
Notice the aliveness in your body—the subtle hum of energy, tingling, or vibration that is always present.
Listen to the sounds of your own breathing. Can you hear the soft whisper of air entering and leaving your body?
Hold the image of the Earth in your mind. Send wishes of peace, healing, and harmony to the planet and all its inhabitants.
Notice the empty space in the room around you. Become aware of the space between objects, and the space in which everything exists.
Watch your thoughts as if you were sitting on a riverbank watching leaves float by. Don't try to grab them; just watch them drift past.
Acknowledge a struggle you are currently facing. Silently tell yourself, 'This is a moment of suffering. Suffering is a part of life. May I be kind to myself.'
Breathe in for a count of four, hold for a count of four, and breathe out for a count of six. Repeat this for a few cycles to calm the nervous system.
Scan your body for any areas that feel good right now—perhaps a sense of warmth, relaxation, or tingling. Rest your attention there.
Gently touch the fingertips of one hand to the fingertips of the other. Notice the sensation of contact with curiosity.
Reflect on the fact that at this very moment, millions of other people are also breathing, thinking, and feeling, just like you.
Listen to a piece of instrumental music. Instead of analyzing it, just let the sounds wash over you. Notice how the vibrations feel in your body.
Notice how emotions are not solid. They are processes that flow and change. Observe the fluid nature of your feelings.
Notice that a thought you had a minute ago is now gone. Where did it go? Acknowledge the transient nature of your mental activity.
Let your exhalation be slightly longer than your inhalation. This can help to activate the body's relaxation response.
Notice the boundary of your skin. Feel the sensation of where 'you' end and the world begins. Explore this edge with your awareness.
Sit with a 'don't know' mind. Let go of any agendas or expectations, and simply be open and receptive to the present moment as it unfolds.
Bring to mind someone who does a difficult or thankless job. Silently acknowledge their contribution and send them a feeling of appreciation.
With your next cup of tea or coffee, take a moment to notice the warmth of the mug, the aroma, and the flavor of the first sip with your full attention.
Instead of getting lost in a thought, mentally 'note' it. 'Worry.' 'Plan.' 'Memory.' This creates a separation that allows for greater awareness.
Bring to mind an animal. Acknowledge its existence and its own desire to live peacefully. Extend a sense of kindness and respect toward it.
As you breathe, imagine you are providing life-giving oxygen to every cell in your body. Feel your breath as a nourishing force.
Notice the weight of your arms resting in your lap or on the armrests. Let gravity do the work and release any effort to hold them up.
Notice how sounds arise from silence and dissolve back into silence. Let your mind rest in that underlying quiet.
Bring to mind someone you admire from afar (an artist, a leader, a historical figure). Send them feelings of gratitude and respect.
Notice the subtle shifts of light in your room as time passes. Observe the gentle dance of brightness and shadow.
Ask yourself: 'Can I be with this feeling for just one more breath?' Practice staying present with your emotions, one moment at a time.
Reflect on the water you drink. Consider its long journey through rivers, clouds, and rain to reach you. Feel your connection to the planet's water cycle.
Observe your breath without any labels or counting. Simply feel the raw physical sensation of breathing.
Bring awareness to your whole body sitting here. Feel its shape, its weight, its presence in this moment.
Notice if there is a scent associated with the room you are in. Is it familiar? Faint? Simply be aware of the olfactory landscape.
Remind yourself that your struggles are part of the human condition. Others have felt this way. You are not alone. Feel the comfort in this shared experience.
During your commute today, take a few moments to notice the sights and sounds outside your window without judgment or story.
If you feel restless, notice the physical sensations of that energy in your body. Observe the urge to move without having to act on it.
Take a moment to be grateful for each of your senses: the ability to see, hear, smell, taste, and touch. Appreciate these gateways to the world.
Feel the breath as it moves through your entire body, not just your lungs. Imagine your toes, fingers, and head breathing in and out.
Notice the contact points between your left and right sides. Where do your hands touch? Do your legs cross? Just be aware.
Let go of your primary anchor (like the breath) and allow your awareness to be open and receptive to whatever is most predominant in your experience moment to moment.
Bring to mind a mistake for which you still carry guilt. Acknowledge the pain it caused, recognize that you did the best you could at the time, and offer yourself forgiveness.
When you brush your teeth, pay attention to the sensation of the bristles, the taste of the toothpaste, and the sound of the brush. Be fully present for this simple act.
When you feel a moment of joy or happiness, pause. Notice where you feel it in your body and allow yourself to fully savor the pleasant sensation.
Recognize that the 'you' of this moment is different from the 'you' of an hour ago. You are not a fixed entity, but a constantly changing process.
Notice the natural, unforced quality of your breath. You don't need to control it. Simply allow it to be as it is.
Feel the aliveness in your fingertips. Notice any tingling, warmth, or pulsing sensations.
Notice the texture of the sounds you hear. Are they sharp, soft, rough, smooth?
Think of someone you know casually. Wish them happiness and well-being, strengthening the sense of positive connection in your social web.
Observe a shadow. Notice its shape, its darkness, and how it changes as the light source moves.
When a desire or craving arises, observe it as a pattern of thought and sensation. Notice its energy without needing to immediately gratify it.
Be grateful for one thing you have learned that has made your life better. Acknowledge the value of that knowledge.
Follow the breath as if it were the most interesting thing in the world. Approach each inhalation and exhalation with fresh curiosity.
Bring awareness to the area around your heart. Notice any sensations of openness, tightness, warmth, or coolness in your chest.
Notice what is still in your environment and what is moving. Be aware of both the dynamic and static aspects of the present moment.
Acknowledge a moment of difficulty ('This is hard'). Recognize it's part of being human ('Others feel this way'). Offer yourself kindness ('May I be kind to myself').
Sit quietly and reflect on your journey so far this year. Acknowledge your efforts, your growth, and your challenges without judgment. Simply be with your story up to this point.
Feel the beginning, middle, and end of your inhalation. Then feel the beginning, middle, and end of your exhalation. Break the breath down into its component parts.
Notice the sensation of gravity holding you to the earth. Feel your weight and the support of the ground or chair beneath you.
Let sounds be just vibrations in the air. Drop the stories and labels about what is making the sound, and just experience the raw sensory data.
Bring to mind the people you will interact with today. Silently wish them a good day, setting an intention of kindness for your interactions.
Look at your reflection in a window or screen. Observe the image without criticism or praise, just as a collection of shapes, colors, and light.
Recognize that you are the observer of your thoughts, not the thoughts themselves. Rest in this spacious awareness that is watching the mind.
Be grateful for your ability to learn and grow. Acknowledge your capacity for change and adaptation.
Imagine your breath is a gentle broom, sweeping your mind clean of clutter with each exhalation.
Bring awareness to your entire skeletal structure. Feel the solid framework that supports your body.
Notice how your mind automatically labels sounds. For a few moments, see if you can just hear the sound without the label.
Acknowledge one of your positive qualities. Silently appreciate this aspect of yourself and offer yourself kindness for it.
If you can see people walking, observe their movements without creating stories about them. Just notice the physical act of walking.
Notice the impermanent, wave-like nature of an emotion. It rises in intensity, crests, and then naturally subsides if you allow it to.
Reflect on a time you were in need and someone helped you. Connect with that feeling of receiving care, and let it fuel your own compassion.
On the in-breath, be aware of the space you are taking up. On the out-breath, be aware of the space around you. Feel the connection between inner and outer space.
Notice the subtle sensation of air on your exposed skin—your face, your hands. Feel the connection with the atmosphere around you.
Place your hands on your lap. Notice the texture of the fabric beneath your palms and fingers.
Recognize that a person you find difficult is also seeking happiness, just like you, even if they do it in unskillful ways. Hold this shared humanity in your awareness.
Notice the geometry in the room: the straight lines of walls and furniture, the circles and squares. See the world as a collection of shapes.
When a thought hooks you, gently and kindly unhook yourself by saying 'thinking' and returning your focus to your breath.
Contemplate that everything you can see, hear, and feel in this moment is temporary and in a state of flux. Rest in this understanding of change.
As you inhale, feel the sense of receiving. As you exhale, feel the sense of letting go. Inhale, receive; exhale, release.
Bring awareness to the space between your eyebrows. Let this area soften and relax.
Sit with an attitude of friendly curiosity toward whatever enters your awareness. 'Ah, this thought.' 'Oh, that sound.' Welcome it all.
Feel gratitude for your own capacity for awareness—this ability to notice your experience as it happens.
When you get up after this meditation, notice the intention to move, the physical process of rising, and the sensation of standing. Bring mindfulness to this simple action.
Notice the difference between a primary emotion (e.g., sadness) and a secondary reaction to it (e.g., anger about being sad). Try to stay with the primary feeling.
Bring to mind the suffering of others in the world. Allow your heart to be touched by this reality and send a wish for their relief.
Follow your breath down into your belly, feeling it expand on the in-breath and gently contract on the out-breath.
Notice any asymmetry in your body. Is one shoulder higher? Are you leaning to one side? Simply observe without needing to correct.
Listen to the overall 'hum' of your environment—the combination of all sounds into a single, complex vibration.
Extend kind wishes to the person you were in the past. Offer that younger version of yourself compassion and understanding.
Notice the process of blinking. Be aware of the brief moment of darkness and the sensation of your eyelids.
Acknowledge the creativity of your mind. It is constantly generating thoughts, plans, and stories. Appreciate this ability without getting lost in the content.
Consider the food you ate today. Reflect on its connection to the sun, the soil, and the rain. Feel your part in this vast web of life.
Notice the rhythm of your breath. Is it fast, slow, deep, shallow? Just observe its natural pace right now.
Bring a sense of warmth and kindness to your awareness as you scan your body. Let your attention be gentle and caring.
Let your gaze soften and unfocus. Take in the whole visual field at once, without focusing on any one object.
When you see other people today, remind yourself: 'This person wants to be happy, just like me. This person experiences pain, just like me.'
Pause for a moment before you enter a new room or start a new task. Take one conscious breath to mark the transition.
If you feel antsy or bored, investigate that feeling. What are its physical sensations? Where is it in your body? Get curious about it.
Think of one person who believes in you. Feel the warmth and support of their confidence in you.
Imagine your breath is a calm, deep lake. Let your mind rest in its stillness.
Feel the sensation of the air as you breathe in and out of your nostrils. Notice the subtle coolness and warmth.
Be aware of your experience in this moment without trying to hold onto it or push it away. Practice radical acceptance of 'what is.'
Extend well-wishes to your future self. 'May my future self be happy. May my future self be healthy. May my future self find peace.'
Notice how your perception of an object changes depending on how close or far away it is. Explore the effect of distance on your senses.
Let go of the need to control your thoughts. Allow them to arise and pass naturally, like bubbles rising to the surface of water.
Reflect that all your current worries and joys are temporary states. This too shall pass. Find a sense of ease in this knowledge.
Breathe in, aware of your body. Breathe out, smiling to your body. Acknowledge your physical presence with kindness.
Notice the subtle energetic quality of your body. Does it feel vibrant, dull, calm, agitated? Just observe.
Notice the direction from which sounds are coming—left, right, in front, behind. Map out your auditory space.
Silently repeat, 'I am enough, just as I am in this moment.' Let the words be a soothing balm.
After you finish using a device, take 60 seconds to just sit. Notice the echo of the screen time in your mind and body before moving on.
Investigate the 'story' attached to an emotion. Notice the narrative your mind creates, and see if you can separate the story from the raw physical sensation.
Be grateful for the sun, which provides warmth and light, fueling all life on Earth. Feel a connection to this vast source of energy.
Imagine your breath reaching every part of your body, from the top of your head to the tips of your toes.
Notice the places in your body that feel neutral—not pleasant or unpleasant. Rest your awareness in this simple, non-dramatic experience.
Feel the subtle movement of air on your skin. Can you detect any gentle currents or breezes in the room?
Bring to mind all the people who have shown you kindness. Let your heart fill with gratitude for the love and support you have received.
Notice the interaction of different textures in your environment. The smoothness of a table, the roughness of a wall, the softness of fabric.
Notice the 'stickiness' of some thoughts. Observe how the mind wants to cling to them, and gently practice the art of letting go, again and again.
Reflect that the atoms making up your body were once part of distant stars. Feel your connection to the vastness of the cosmos.
On your next in-breath, silently say 'calm'. On your next out-breath, silently say 'ease'. Inhale calm, exhale ease.
Bring a gentle curiosity to your physical sensations. Approach your body not with a goal, but with an open-ended question: 'What is here right now?'
Rest in the awareness that is aware. Notice the quality of consciousness itself—the simple fact that you are experiencing this moment.
Think of someone you know who is happy and thriving. Rejoice in their happiness (this is called 'sympathetic joy' or 'mudita').
Perform a simple, everyday action—like picking up a cup—with the precision and care of a sacred ritual. Notice every detail of the movement.
If there is physical pain, separate the raw sensation from the mental story about it ('This is awful, it will never end'). Just stay with the pure sensation for a breath.
Be grateful for your own resilience. Acknowledge all the challenges you have already survived and navigated in your life.
Let your breath be a reminder to return to the present moment, over and over again.
Notice the space your body occupies. Feel your own physical presence in the room.
Pay attention to the vibrational quality of sounds. Feel them as energy moving through the air and your body.
Silently say to yourself: 'May I accept myself just as I am.' Offer yourself radical acceptance in this moment.
Observe the natural world outside your window. Notice the signs of life, change, and the current season.
Notice how thoughts often come in chains. See if you can catch the moment one thought links to the next, creating a story.
Reflect on a happy memory. Acknowledge that the moment has passed, and appreciate it as a precious part of your history, without clinging.
Breathe in, aware of your whole body. Breathe out, releasing all tension. Let your breath soothe your entire physical being.
Bring awareness to your internal organs—your stomach, lungs, heart. Sense the quiet, constant work happening inside you.
Notice the constant stream of experience: sights, sounds, thoughts, feelings. Let it all flow without needing to grasp or control any of it.
Consider the simple act of breathing. At this very moment, billions of others are sharing this fundamental experience of life with you.
Before you speak today, take a brief pause. Consider if your words are true, necessary, and kind.
Imagine a difficult emotion as a small child needing attention. Turn toward it with kindness and care, rather than pushing it away.
Be grateful for the challenges that have shaped you and taught you important lessons.
